job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Cafeteria is good and friendly. Be prepared to eat a slice of cake every lunch break of every day because it is the only sliver of joy you will have in your dreadful life working here. You'll gain weight but it won't matter because you're dead inside anyway. Your management will make you feel guilty for taking your mandatory lunch break, and you'll be expected to work harder and longer to "make up" for that time.
cons:
If you care about your health, and the health of patients and those around you, do not give Banner Health an extra second of your thought or time. I was brought in as a college graduate, a fast-learner and a determined worker into a new field I was to be trained in. Sterile Processing is not easy, but it is significant in the safety of patients in surgical and diagnostic procedures. I was trained for two weeks, and the management changed. This wouldn't be a problem normally, but instead of finding a new leader, I was left to a kind but elderly co-worker who was nearing retirement in a physically and mentally demanding job, to be trained while on the job. Mistakes are potentially life-threatening if not caught, and with the workload continuing as 'normal', this was more than a challenge. This co-worker chose not to wear a mask during the height of COVID-19 in a HOSPITAL setting, in close quarters with me in our department despite my worries contracting COVID and potentially spreading to my immunocompromised family that I had made clear previously many times. She contracted COVID-19. She was subsequently gone for months. With about a month of training (which is not enough for such a clinical setting with so many complicated and important processes), I was left alone in the Sterile Processing Department and expected to perform the duties perfectly, as patient's lives were on the line (we are INFECTION PREVENTION). They brought over a manager from McKey, who stayed in the office all day rather than help me prepare for surgeries and perform my duties that were so extensive, I was working ten to twelve hour days on a regular just to try and keep up with daily surgeries that were scheduled. My compensation does not change throughout this, mind you. I am on call 24/7, 7 days a week, at $2 an hour BEFORE tax. I ask my temporary manager if I could have one Saturday off, if someone from McKey, who have refused to come help, could take my on-call. It is made clear this is "very difficult" for her to do, that I am an inconvenience. Just like when I come back from the bathroom after holding it all morning for her to inquire where I was, or condescendingly say, "Oh THERE you are." as if I am not holding the department up on my shoulders alone. Don't you dare try and take a fifteen minute break, even if it's legal and in the handbook. You'll regret the passive aggressiveness thrown back at you. Prepare to be uncomfortable, the scrub techs are just generally unsanitary, which is upsettingly ironic, and it is clear with how they talk about patients and take everything with a dose of lackadaisical nonchalance that your family member on the table means absolutely nothing to them. In Sterile Processing, cleaning takes a "three sink" process, one for initial wash and scrub, another for soak, and the last for rinse (usually with reverse-osmosis water). This facility has two sinks. One in which I was expected to work, while next to me someone from the G.I lab cleans a colonoscopy scope within inches of each other. Disgusting does not begin to describe this practice. The washers are clunky and old, they opened up right to my desk so I got to enjoy a nice near-burning steam cloud every half hour or so if I didn't realize it was about to open and time myself right to move. The room is left hot, and then with all the machinery going, it's boiling and nauseating. It is not made for functionality for anyone or anything, and it's a miracle any instruments are processed correctly with how little time or funds go into this department--so if your family member contracts an infection, don't be surprised. Joint Commission didn't visit on normal terms due to the pandemic, but if they'd made it while I was there, they would've had a fit and the hospital would no doubt have been shut down from this department alone. Don't bother talking to the management, including the person above the supervisor. I was told in two different meetings I had to schedule that it was just "hard to find people right now", as if this were a fast food restaurant and not a medical facility with peoples lives and quality of life at stake. They will suck the life out of you. Your time, your effort, your care for others until you have nothing but an empty shell of yourself left--and then they'll have you stay longer so your manager can go home. I have never left a job same-day. I have never left a job in sobs either. I was berated, yelled at (screamed at, really, it's a miracle half the hospital didn't hear), gaslit and told it was my fault the surgeries would be cancelled for the week--as if it wasn't their fault for not hiring or having help come over to make this place function. My physical and mental health took a toll, to say the least, and to say they do not care is an understatement. They'd rather have a zombie body there to put the blame on when they eventually get into trouble for their negligence, than make an effort to keep patients safe and employees want to stay. This is all besides the fact every person I've ever known who has been a patient at this location has had near-death experiences due to their lack of care in every sector. They won't care about you either. Do not work here. Do not work for Banner. Do not work at a medical facility that calls their patients "customers.".

They’ll try and make it seem like I’m unhinged, or as if I were the problem, it’s just a testament to their lack of accountability.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Phoenix, AZ
pros: -Some nurses are great and have a wealth of information as well as providing a good support system. -Pay is decent -mostly flexible with your schedule -I had great dealings with my immediate manager who did her best to retain employees but her hands were constantly tied due to management above her making decisions she had no power over.
cons: -Educators- I personally felt they were given far too much power and was personally ied to multiple times by them. It got to the point where i refused to communicate with them outside of an email where things were in writing. -An immense corporate entity that will remind you constantly that you can and will be replaced. -You will be put in positions if you float where you are unfamiliar with how things are done. The turnover is so high that it's not uncommon to be floated to a unit that is only travelers and floats. No core staff to provide guidance on how things are done. -Some nurses are extremely and utterly toxic that have used the fact turnover is so high as a chance to move up in into positions like charge nurses. Management has no other choice that to turn a blind eye to this as they need nurses and will reward the employees that have chosen to stay. As I said no two units/hospitals are the same, some are very supportive and will do their best to build you up as a nurse so you can be a strong addition to their team. However, others will have nurses who do their best to break you down in order to build themselves up. I began floating and would get horrible anxiety going to some units as I knew I had to be constantly looking over my shoulder with nurses looking to exploit any mistake you may make in your night. These bully nurses seem to thrive on forcing new grads to quit and will often see as a sign of accomplishment.

pros: Getting to work from home full-time once the pandemic started.

I had a successful career, which stopped dead when I came to Banner. My manager didn’t know how to leverage my skill set so my strengths were underutilized, and she had no clue how to train, mentor or motivate. She mocked and made fun of other employees behind their backs, and she seemed to sow conflict and mistrust between those working under her.

The job at Banner that was described to me in my interviews was not the job I got, the people were not the supportive and friendly types I’d expected, and the compensation was extremely poor. (I took a pay cut when I was hired, and I was still making less when I left in 2021 than I had been making in my job before Banner).

If anyone reading this is really focused on Banner as an employer, my advice is to not be afraid to negotiate salary.

review_title: Progressive thinking team making headway in Healthcare
pros:
The Digital Business team is forward-thinking, pushing the boundaries of what's possible in an established healthcare system. If you like challenging work that makes a difference and you have the perseverance to see it through, then this is a great place to work! The management team is aligned in its vision and we currently have a large amount of support from the board and senior leadership. The products we're creating will help people get easier access to care and will make managing their care easier. Team members get recognized for their accomplishments and there is a culture of collaboration that is influencing the larger organization. 
The CEO was volunteering on the front lines to deliver COVID testing and vaccines during the pandemic. He gave regular video updates to keep us motivated and aware of team members efforts, struggles, and victories.
cons: Change is slow and hard in a large established organization. System capabilities are limited so we're faced with constant challenges to realizing our vision. This means that projects often have multiple phases to get to the outcome we desire. It requires patience to see it through.

I should first say that this review is more of a review of the Tucson UMC Inpatient Pharmacy rather than the whole hospital or company.  This department is an absolute mess and is truly an embarrassment. Management (or lack thereof) has created a negative and sometimes hostile environment that is almost impossible to work in. They are extremely dismissive to anyone below them, does not provide proper or adequate training to new employees, shows a huge lack of respect to their employees, and is extremely negligent which has led to multiple injuries to their techs and then shows no concern for those that are injured. 
The pharmacy is almost always short staffed due to continuous call outs from unreliable employees and/or employees who are burnt out or exhausted to the point of illness. The tech managers have no idea what their employees jobs actually entail and constantly change the workflow without speaking to those that do the job. In addition, their lack of knowledge and training for any of the positions means they are not able to help when the pharmacy is short staffed, even if they wanted to. It is extremely sad to see what this pharmacy has become over the years.

pros: Good networking, management prior to 2019 was solid, the workload was pretty much the same no matter where you went; easy to transfer to another department; system is big so the provider availability is good; insurance benefits were decent; Banner hospitalists and specialists were great to work with and treated me with respect; dietary very responsive to patient and unit requests; laboratory very fast and efficient staff; respiratory therapy and lines team top notch crew; pharmacy both inpatient and outpatient were fabulous
cons: Always texting and calling you to work extra shifts when already worked to the bone, yet they would be on your case about overtime; no weekend differential; no on-call pay (you get cancelled and called back—sorry, but that’s on-call); experienced nurses had to float often and new grads did not, which in turn made new grads not adaptable to change or variations in workflow; some staff would disappear for hours, usually fooling around with ancillary staff or on another unit talking to a friend; very little work life balance as you are practically married to your job; advertised as needing 100s of nurses yet laid off my entire department in less than a month and did not notify staff, providers, or patients in a fair timeframe; attempting to force nurses to work bedside when some nurses are highly specialized at non-bedside positions; very little appreciation from the administration other than motivational emails and videos—-once they provided food trucks free of charge during a Covid surge so healthcare workers were congregated outside of the hospital (how smart!); beginning of the pandemic, administration came around and demanded we take off masks to not scare or intimidate the patients; environmental services was horrendously slow and bad about responding to requests; only 1 or 2 housekeepers actually worked well; zero hazard pay during the pandemic whatsoever; working as a floor nurse there for 2 years is practically considered a veteran; holds a charity period every year to have the staff raise money for their own employees (I know other systems do it but I think it’s a stupid concept to keep the system from taking care of its employees—-nonprofit status is a joke)

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Sun City, AZ
pros:
Worked on observation as a patient care texh. Loved my nurses. Best teamwork spirit I've ever worked with. 
Almost always had the tools I needed to do my job. 
Everyone is pretty friendly.
cons:
The last review I had really made me angry. My manager had nothing but good things to say about my job performance. Also said she never got complaints about me. 
However, I lost points (they said it was hospital wide, which doesn't make it any better) because the hospital didn't meet retention goals for employees. 
I also lost points because I didn't meet my personal goal. When I was hired I wasn't given one. So I lost points for not meeting a goal I wasn't given. 
In the end, I was given a 20 cent raise. I thought the whole process was pretty demoralizing. 
I heard from people who've been here a while that banner used to give Christmas bonuses. My bonus last year was a $5 gift certificate to the cafeteria. 
When hired, nurses are told thathat the max patients they will ever get would be 5 but that 4 should be the normal. They are almost always maxed out at 5. There are supposed to be 3 techs to a floor. But there are almost always only 2. So we usually have 15 patients to ourselves. Which can be exhausting. 
Also they only give away one scholarships per year. Sucks when almost everyone i talk to is in school trying to better themselves so they can get a better job in the company.

I would reiterate what was said previously- management sucks.  The system is based on cronyism, with promotion from within.  There are way too many people who simply fill a job title and are either not qualified or lack serious vision, lack the intelligence and experience, and seem to be collecting a paycheck.  Nobody can be removed from a management position barring an act of God. 

 The mission statement is highly misleading, since roadblocks to providing excellent patient care are constantly put up by anyone at a management level.  Too much passing the buck - nobody really makes a decision, it simply gets passed on to the next person, or corporate, or whomever.  Corporate office makes decisions that affect patient care without really understanding what is going on in the facility.  When you look at the "health system", why is it that there are not more health professionals (doctors and nurses) in management positions?  It is all business people.  That seems a strange way to run a medical business.

review_title: Banner Health - I can no longer recommend them as a good place to work.
pros: Large size company with locations in several different states and opportunities exist to transfer between hospitals. My experience is limited to the Phoenix metro area but I would like to say we have modern facilities with quality equipment to do our jobs.
cons: Micromanagement can be a problem when 3 or 4 different managers have to talk to you about the same issue. Recently management has came up with "cost cutting measures" that are supposed to "guide the company through the country's economic downturn." The vast majority of these are cutting or eliminating employee benefits. Examples include cutting tuition reimbursement for employees who were not enrolled in a degree program prior to 2009, cutting how quickly employees that have been with the company more than 3 years accrue paid time off, eliminating the option of cashing out your earned paid time off, decreasing the amount of pay for short term disability, too much contracted labor (travel nurses, etc.) has recently become a problem when the regular staff members cannot even work their full time hours and have to use paid time off to receive a full paycheck.

pros: helping environment amongst staff members
cons: always short staffed and always high acuity for patient ratios

pros: Work is consistent and keeps you busy

review_title: It's a job. It has it's ups and downs like anything else.
pros: Flexible schedule in most cases. The ability to help others. In most cases you can speak candidly with your immediate supervisor. A majority, (but not all) of the doctors are pleasant people and easy to talk to. A lot of the staff you get to know have the same concerns and somewhat feel united in our frustration with the system as a whole.
cons: Elitest and pack mentality of certain floors and departments. If you can't come to work and know you are in a stable environment with a company who shares your values, it gets to be difficult. Banner has been good about stoking a fire but seems to fall short in maintaining it. As in every corporate job, there are people who are paid to stir things up to justify their leadership and later fall asleep at the wheel. The tuition reimbursement cutback is a travesty. For those of us who joined these hospitals with the intent of making Banner and medicine our lives, we haved been cheated. We are falling short of our goals due to the breaking of a promise made when we were hired.  I joined Banner in great part for the tuition benefit which is no longer available to me after substantial service to THEIR causes.

pros:
If you code blue they might be able to revive you. 

The people are generally good. Banner cleaned house of many ineffective VPs from the old organization (don't know if the replacements are any better).
cons:
HS&E is severely under resourced. Want to be a one-person show for 6500+ employees and 10+ locations? That is what they expect from you. Ask how many Safety Officers they have had in the last two years. Ask how long each one lasted. The first lasted less than three months and the second stuck it out for about 10 months. There used to be ~3.5 positions three years ago. 

The organization as a whole doesn't really care about HS&E (even when it was UMC years ago). Nurses are too busy to be trained, docs (ha!) don't follow the rules. The ED can't train in first receiver CBRNE because they are too busy. Not slamming the patient care departments, they have minimum head count so they really don't have time to train, but management does not support the training by providing time to train. Ask how (if) OSHA recordables are investigated and if corrective actions are identified and completed. 

Pay is not competitive in the Tucson market.
